https://s3.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-us-east/content/pii:S2468823118301457/STRIPIN/image/gif/5a3e7dfe79c6fb25750711fddafa4dcb/si5.gif si5 si5.gif gif 405 25 192 ALTIMG MCAT 551 S2468-8231(18)30145-7 10.1016/j.mcat.2018.04.014 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 NH3-SCR activity (a) and N2 selectivity (b) of Ce10/Ti and Ce10P x /Ti catalysts as a function of temperature. Reaction conditions: catalyst of 0.15 g, 500ppmNO, 500ppmNH3, 3%O2, N2 balanced, total flow rate: 100 or 400 mL/min. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 NH3-SCR activity of Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti catalysts as a function of temperature. Reaction conditions: catalyst of 0.15 g, 500ppmNO, 500ppmNH3, 3%, 6% or 9% O2, N2 balanced, total flow rate: 200 mL/min corresponding to a GHSV of 60,000 h−1. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 The effects of H2O (a) and H2O + SO2 (b) on SCR activity over Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti catalysts at 250 °C. Reaction conditions: catalyst of 0.15 g, 500ppmNO, 500ppmNH3, 3% O2, 150 ppm SO2, 5% H2O, N2 balanced, total flow rate: 200 mL/min. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) XRD patterns Ce10/Ti and Ce10P x /Ti catalysts; (b) XRD patterns Ce10P4/Ti, Ce20P8/Ti and Ce30P12/Ti catalysts (c) P 2p XPS spectra of Ce10P3/Ti catalyst. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 NO oxidation results of Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti catalysts. Reaction conditions: catalyst of 0.15 g, 500ppmNO, 3% O2, N2 balanced, total flow rate: 200 mL/min. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) Ce 3d XPS spectra of Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti catalysts; (b) O 1s XPS spectra of Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 NH3-TPD profiles of Ce10/Ti and Ce10P x /Ti catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 H2-TPR profiles of Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti catalysts. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 In-situ DRIFT spectra of NO + O2 reacted with pre-adsorbed NH3 species over Ce10/Ti (a) and Ce10P3/Ti (b). Conditions: 200 °C, 500ppmNO, 500ppmNH3, 3% O2, N2 balanced, total flow rate: 100 mL/min. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 In-situ DRIFT spectra of NH3 reacted with pre-adsorbed NO x species over Ce10/Ti (a) and Ce10P3/Ti (b). Conditions: 200 °C, 500ppmNO, 500ppmNH3, 3% O2, N2 balanced, total flow rate: 100 mL/min. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Proposed reaction path of NH3-SCR over CeO2/TiO2 and phosphorus-doping CeO2/TiO2. Fig. 11 Table 1 The BET specific surface area and total acidity of Ce10/Ti and Ce10P x /Ti catalysts. Table 1 Sample BET specific surface area (m2/g) Total acidity (μmol/g) Ce10/Ti 53 68.6 Ce10P1/Ti 55 65.2 Ce10P2/Ti 55 61.2 Ce10P3/Ti 51 58.4 Ce10P4/Ti 53 54.1 Table 2 The fitting data of XPS results over Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti catalysts. Table 2 Sample Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) Oα/(Oα + Oβ) Ce10/Ti 23.3% 6.3% Ce10P3/Ti 49.5% 33.0% The promoting effects of amorphous CePO4 species on phosphorus-doped CeO2/TiO2 catalysts for selective catalytic reduction of NO x by NH3 Yanchen You a Chuanning Shi a Huazhen Chang a ⁎ Lei Guo a Liwen Xu a Junhua Li b a School of Environment and Natural Resources, Renmin University of China, Beijing, 100872, China School of Environment and Natural Resources Renming University of China Beijing 100872 China b School of Environment, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China School of Environment Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A series of phosphorus-doped CeO2/TiO2 catalysts were prepared by impregnation method and the effects of P on NH3-SCR performance over CeO2/TiO2 were investigated. The P-doped catalysts showed much better deNO x performance than Ce10/Ti catalyst. It was found that the optimal phosphorus loading was 3 wt.% (calculated as P2O5). The Ce10P3/Ti catalyst also exhibited excellent resistance to H2O. The samples were characterized by BET, XRD, XPS, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR and in-situ DRIFT studies. It was found that the ratio of surface Ce3+ and surface adsorbed oxygen species were promoted by phosphorus doping, thus the transfer of surface oxygen and the regeneration of active sites could be accelerated accordingly. Moreover, it was confirmed that the amorphous CePO4 appeared with excellent redox property after the doping of phosphorus. The amorphous CePO4 species could promote NH3-SCR activity by activating NH4 + species on the Brønsted acid sites of phosphate radical, forming NH2 intermediates to react with gaseous NO via an Eley–Rideal mechanism. Keywords NH3-SCR CeO2/TiO2 catalyst Phosphorus-doping Impregnation method Amorphous CePO4 species 1 Introduction Stationary and mobile sources emissions of nitrogen oxides (NO x ) contribute much atmospheric pollution like acid rain and photochemical smog [1,2]. Selective catalytic reduction of NO x by ammonia (NH3-SCR) is proved to be an excellent technique for NO x elimination [2,3]. The V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 are the most widely-used commercial catalysts in NH3-SCR [3–6]. However, there are several shortages for these catalysts that need to be improved, such as the toxicity of vanadium to the environment, the narrow operating temperature window, and low N2 selectivity (i.e. N2O formation) at high temperature, especially over V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst [4,7]. Therefore, development of non-vanadium NH3-SCR catalysts received increasing attention in recent years. These researches focused on transition metal and rare earth metal catalysts, such as Fe, Mn, Cu, Ce, Zr-based catalysts [8–12]. Among the elements investigated in literatures, cerium attracted increasing consideration as active components or promoters [13,14]. Recently, the Ce-based catalysts were investigated extensively because of its excellent redox property and outstanding oxygen storage capacity of CeO2 [15–18]. In NH3-SCR, the CeO2/TiO2 catalysts exhibited notable catalytic activity from 300 to 400 °C, and excellent N2 selectivity even at high temperature [19]. In addition, the CeO2/TiO2 catalysts showed better resistance to H2O and SO2 than commercial V-based catalysts [20,21]. The CeOTi short-range order species were confirmed as the active sites over amorphous CeO2/TiO2 catalyst [22]. Therefore, the CeO2/TiO2 catalysts may be an excellent candidate for NH3-SCR because of their notable activity, excellent N2 selectivity and environmentally-benign characteristics. Doping of specific element into CeO2/TiO2 to enhance its performance has received much attention. It was reported that several metallic elements, such as Sn [23,24], W [25,26], Mo [27,28], Fe [29], Cu [30], Mn [8,31], as well as non-metallic elements (such as Si [32], F [33]), helped to improve the NH3-SCR performance over CeO2/TiO2 in some respects. Recently, the deactivation effects of phosphorus-containing compounds to the NH3-SCR catalysts from flue gas have been designated [34,35]. Phosphates showed promising properties such as acidity, thermal stability and ion exchange. It might be promising promoter for NH3-SCR catalyst [36]. It was reported that superior activity was obtained at 200–400 °C over CePO mixed oxides catalyst and it might be a promising alternative catalyst for NH3-SCR technology [37–39]. Other researchers reported that impregnation with H3PO4 solution could also improve the NH3-SCR activity over CeO2 [40]. The above results suggested doping of phosphorus into Ce-based catalysts is beneficial for NH3-SCR performance. In this work, a series of novel phosphorus-doping CeO2/TiO2 catalysts were synthesized by simple impregnation method. A dramatic improvement of deNO x activity and resistance to H2O and excess oxygen could be observed over these catalysts. To the best of our knowledge, the phosphorus-doping CeO2/TiO2 catalysts showed outstanding deNO x performance among the Ce-based NH3-SCR catalysts prepared by impregnation method. The promoting effects of phosphorus doping to CeO2/TiO2 was also investigated extensively by means of BET, XRD, XPS, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR and in-situ DRIFT experiments. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The CeO2/TiO2 catalyst with a mass fraction of 10 wt.% CeO2 was synthesized by impregnation method. A certain amount of commercial TiO2 P25 was added into an aqueous solution of cerium nitrate. The mixture was stirred mildly till excess water was removed, then followed by drying at 100 °C overnight and calcination at 500 °C for 4 h. The catalyst is denoted as Ce10/Ti. The P-doped CeO2/TiO2 catalyst was prepared by impregnating corresponding amounts of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and NH4H2PO4 on TiO2 P25. A certain amount of nitric acid was added into the mixture of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and NH4H2PO4 solution to inhibit the hydrolysis of dihydrogen phosphate. Then the mixture underwent the same experimental procedures as Ce10/Ti catalyst. The phosphorus-doped catalysts are denoted as Ce10P x /Ti, where x wt.% represents the mass fraction of P2O5 (x = 1, 2, 3, 4), 10 represents the mass fraction of CeO2. In addition, the Ce20P8/Ti and Ce30P12/Ti catalyst (the molar ratio of Ce/P was kept about 1, the same as Ce10P4/Ti) with high amounts of cerium and phosphorus was also prepared. 2.2 Catalytic performance test The steady-state NH3−SCR performance was tested in a fixed-bed quartz reactor with the following reaction conditions: 500 ppm NH3, 500 ppm NO, 3% (or 6%, 9%) O2, N2 balanced, 0.15 g catalyst. The oxidation of NO and temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) were tested in the same reactor. The concentrations of N2O, NO, NO2, NH3 were determined by a IR gas analyzer (Gasmet Dx-4000). The catalytic activity was characterized by NO conversion: N O c o n v e r s i o n = [ N O ] i n − [ N O ] o u t − [ N H 4 N O 3 ] solid [ N O ] i n × 100 % The N2 selectivity could be calculated from: N 2 selectivity = { 1 − 2 [ N 2 O ] [ N O x ] i n + [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N O x ] o u t − [ N H 3 ] out − 2 [ N H 4 N O 3 ] solid } × 100 % where [NOx]in , [NH3]in , [NOx]out , and [NH3]out stands for the inlet and outlet concentrations of NO x and NH3, separately. The quantity of [NH4NO3]solid was determined by ultraviolet spectrophotometry and ion chromatography. Ultraviolet spectrophotometry was used to detect NH4 +, and ion chromatography was used to detect NO3 −. And it was confirmed that there was nearly no NH4NO3 formed over Ce10/Ti and Ce10Px/Ti catalysts. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Powder XRD pattern measurement was carried out on an X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, D/max-2200/PC, Japan) between 10 and 90° with a rate of 10° min−1. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area was measured by a Quantachrome Nova specific surface area analyzer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement was determined on an electron spectrometer (ESCALab220i-XL, VG Scientific). In NH3-TPD experiment, 0.15 g catalyst and 200 mL min−1 gas flow rate were used. Temperature-programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR) profiles were recorded on a ChemiSorb 2720 TPx chemisorption analyzer from Micromeritics under a 30 mL min−1 gas flow (10% H2/Ar), 10 °C min−1 heating rate up to 1000 °C. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTS) was performed on a Nicolet iS50 (Thermo Fisher Scientific) infrared spectrometer. The sample underwent degasification in a N2 flow at 400 for 1 h before background scanning and spectra collection at 200 °C. After that, the operational steps were as follows: (1) adsorption in a 500 ppm NH3 (or 500 ppm NO + 3% O2) +N2 flow for 30 min; (2) removal of physically-adsorbed NH3 (or NO x species) in a N2 flow for 30 min; (3) introduction of 500 ppm NO + 3% O2 (or 500 ppm NH3) and DRIFT spectra collection. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effects of phosphorus on NH3-SCR 3.1.1 Catalytic performance Fig. 1 (a) exhibits the NH3-SCR activity of Ce10/Ti and Ce10P x /Ti catalysts under GHSV of 30,000 and 120,000 h−1. Under higher GHSV, the NO conversion was improved till 3 wt.% phosphorus was doped, then it started to decreased with increased amount of P. The Ce10P3/Ti catalyst exhibited the best activity and more than 80% NO conversion could be obtained at 250 °C. For comparison, similar activity could be obtained over Ce10/Ti at 350 °C. Under lower GHSV, the deNO x performance was further enhanced, 80% NO conversion was obtained over Ce10P3/Ti at 200 °C. The doping of P broadened the working temperature window (about 250–400 °C). As a whole, it was clear that doping of P promoted the SCR activity significantly. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 1(b), excellent N2 selectivity could be observed over Ce10/Ti and Ce10P x /Ti catalysts from 100 to 400 °C. Almost 100% N2 selectivity was obtained over all catalysts even at high temperature. It implied that the N2 selectivity was not affected by doping of phosphorus over Ce10/Ti. 3.1.2 The effects of O2 concentration The effect of O2 concentration on NH3-SCR activity over Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti was studied, the results are shown in Fig. 2 . From 100 to 300 °C, the best SCR activity over Ce10/Ti was obtained under 6% O2 concentration. After 300 °C, the NO conversion decreased with the increase of O2 concentration, it might be due to the over oxidation of NH3 to NO. The results indicated that slightly excess oxygen might be beneficial for the deNO x performance but the SCR activity over Ce10/Ti would be influenced seriously under oxygen-rich conditions, especially at high temperature. For Ce10P3/Ti, the SCR activity was promoted significantly with increasing O2 concentration from 100 to 300 °C. At temperatures higher than 300 °C, the NO was completely eliminated with 3% and 6% O2, but the SCR activity was inhibited seriously at high temperature when O2 concentration was 9%. So Thus, the optimal O2 concentration might be around 6% in SCR progress over Ce10P3/Ti. In addition, the SCR activity over Ce10P3/Ti from 300 to 400 °C was not affected by 6% O2, while an obvious decline of activity was observed for Ce10/Ti. Under 9% O2 concentration, Ce10P3/Ti showed better performance than Ce10/Ti. It suggested that the doping of phosphorus enhanced the resistance to oxygen–rich condition over Ce10/Ti. As mentioned above, there are some other reports for the P-doped catalysts and their NH3-SCR activity [35,39–41]. By comparing T10, T90 and synthetic procedure, it was concluded that our P-doped Ce/Ti catalyst owned very excellent catalytic property and also the fairly convenient synthetic method, which make it a promising candidate for practical application. 3.1.3 The effects of H2O and SO2 The effects of H2O and SO2 on Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti are presented in Fig. 3 . At 250 °C, after the introduction of 5% H2O, the NO conversion declined from ca. 55% to 37% over Ce10/Ti. For Ce10P3/Ti, however, the NO conversion declined from 99% to 82%, which was much higher than that of Ce10/Ti. It indicated that the Ce10P3/Ti catalyst had better resistance under wet conditions. After cutting off 5% H2O, the SCR activity recovered in a short time over both of Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti catalysts. It was reported that the reversible deactivation of H2O might result from the competitive adsorption of H2O and NH3 on active sites [20]. Fig. 3(b) showed the effects of H2O and SO2 on the deNO x performance over Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti catalysts. After the introduction of 5% H2O and 150 ppm SO2, the SCR activity over Ce10/Ti dropped quickly to 33% and kept stable. After cutting off H2O + SO2, the activity recovered gradually. For Ce10P3/Ti, the NO conversion dropped rapidly to 71% and then decreased slowly after introduction of H2O and SO2. The quick drop might result from the competitive adsorption of H2O and SO2 and the slow decrease might be due to the accumulation of ammonium phosphate. The introduction of SO2 further deactivated the catalytic performance of both Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti. Then H2O and SO2 were removed from the inlet gas and the SCR activity was fully recovered immediately. The differences of recovery time were possibly due to the amounts of ammonium phosphate accumulated on the surface. 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 XRD patterns The XRD patterns of Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti catalysts were shown in Fig. 4 (a). A weak peak at 33.1° corresponding to CeO2 crystalline phase (JCPDS 34-0394) could be observed for the diffraction pattern of Ce10/Ti, which suggested the existence of crystal CeO x on TiO2. The positive Ce3+/Ce4+ and Ti4+ were linked by negative O2−. And in further consideration of the crystal texture of CeO2, the existence of both CeOTi and CeOCe species on the surface of Ce10/Ti could be concluded accordingly [21,22]. It was reported that the amorphous CeOTi species was confirmed as the active sites of Ce10/Ti rather than CeOCe species [22]. After the doping of phosphorus, the phase of CeO2 disappeared. Meanwhile, a weak peak at 31.4° ascribed to CePO4 monazite (JCPDS 32-0199) were observed in the diffraction patterns of Ce10P3/Ti and Ce10P4/Ti. The disappearance of CeO2 phase might be due to the formation of CePO4. To confirm the peak weak peak at 31.4°, the P-doped CeO2/TiO2 catalysts with high amounts of cerium and phosphorus was prepared and their XRD patterns are shown in Fig. 4(b). Obvious diffraction peaks of CePO4 appeared with the increasing of phosphorus amounts. The intensity of peak at 29.2° and 31.4° are the strongest. But the strong peak at 29.2° overlapped with the diffraction peak of CeO2 over Ce10P4/Ti catalyst. Considering with the diffraction patterns of Ce20P8/Ti and Ce30P12/Ti, the qualitative determination of CePO4 crystalline phase on Ce10P3/Ti and Ce10P4/Ti is reliable. After doping only a certain quantity of phosphorus, surface CePO4 could exist in an amorphous form because of enough specific surface area. With increased amount of phosphorus doping, the phase of monazite CePO4 was detected because of the accumulation of CePO4. In addition, the P 2p XPS spectrum of Ce10P3/Ti is shown in Fig. 4(c). Only a peak around 133.4 eV was observed, which could be ascribed to the electronic state of P 2p of CePO4 [42]. Considering the results with XRD patterns of Ce10P3/Ti, it could be concluded that the precursor NH4H2PO4 turned into a phosphate radical, which easily formed cerous phosphate after calcination. 3.2.2 BET specific surface area and NO oxidation results In NH3-SCR, higher specific surface area avails the adsorption of reactants on the surface, usually leading to a better deNO x activity [3,5]. Table 1 manifested that the BET specific surface area changed a little after doping of phosphorus. It means doping of phosphorus influenced the surface area of Ce10/Ti little. These values were close to that of commercial TiO2 P25, which suggested that the impregnation of cerium and phosphorus had little effect on the structural and textural characteristic of TiO2. The oxidation of NO to NO2 can improve the low temperature NH3-SCR activity by following reaction route which is called “fast SCR”, the order-of-magnitude increase of deNO x rate was observed when the molar ratio of NO/NO2 is 1, especially at lower temperature [43,44]: (1) N O 2 + N O + 2 N H → 3 2 N 2 + 3 H 2 O The NO oxidation results are shown in Fig. 5 . From 100 to 300 °C, the NO oxidation efficiency was quite low (less than 6%) and nearly the same over Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti catalysts. After 300 °C, the NO conversion increased substantially, and a little higher NO conversion was obtained over Ce10P3/Ti. But the gaps of deNO x activity mainly existed below 300 °C over two catalysts. Therefore, the promotion of SCR activity could hardly result from “fast SCR” route. 3.2.3 XPS analysis XPS analysis was conducted to illustrate the surface component and chemical state. Fig. 6 (a) shows the Ce 3d spectra, the bands labeled as u stand for 3d3/2 spin–orbit states and those labeled as v represented 3d5/2 states. The u′ and v′ bands were ascribed to surface Ce3+, and those u and v, u″ and v″, u‴ and v‴ bands were assigned to surface Ce4+. By performing a data fitting with XPS 4.1, eight bands were observed over both Ce10P3/Ti and Ce10/Ti catalysts. Comparing to Ce10/Ti catalyst, the u′ and v′ peaks of Ce10P3/Ti catalyst were more intense, which indicates the increase in the amounts of Ce3+ on the surface. In addition, the bigger peak areas suggested more Ce species on the surface of Ce10P3/Ti than Ce10/Ti catalyst. The O 1s spectra are shown in Fig. 6(b). The band at 531.2 and 529.8 eV could be attributed to surface adsorbed oxygen species (Oα) and lattice oxygen (Oβ), respectively [35]. The fitting data stated that the intensity of Oα peak increased remarkably after doping of phosphorus. That’s to say, the amount of surface adsorbed oxygen species was significantly enhanced by doping phosphorus on Ce10/Ti. As listed in Table 2 , the relative contents of surface Ce3+ increased from 23.3% (on Ce10/Ti) to 49.5% (on Ce10P3/Ti), the relative contents of surface adsorbed oxygen species increased from 6.3% to 33.0%. Surface adsorbed oxygen was supposed to be most active in NH3-SCR reaction. The enhancement of the ratio of surface Ce3+ and adsorbed oxygen could accelerate the transfer of oxygen on the surface and the regeneration of active sites by an oxidation-reduction cycle (Eqs. (2) and (3)), thus promoting NH3-SCR activity [16,45]. (2) O 2 → O 2 2 − (3) 2 C e 3 + + O 2 2 − → 2 C e 4 + + 2 O 2 − 3.2.4 NH3-TPD results There is a general agreement that the NH3-SCR starts with the adsorption of NH3 and better acidity (characterized by NH3 adsorption capacity) is beneficial for catalytic performance [3,4]. The NH3-TPD profiles over Ce10/Ti and Ce10P x /Ti are shown in Fig. 7 . The NH3 adsorption capacity decreased obviously with the increased P-doping amount. Beyond that, the desorption peak shifted to lower temperature with the increase amount of phosphorus doping. It was reported that the doping of phosphorus could provide more Brønsted acid sites for NH3 adsorption, thus improving the acidity [46]. The weakening of total acidity (concluded in Table 1) implied that the Lewis acid sites might decrease significantly after doping of phosphorus. Additionally, NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites are usually more stable than that on Brønsted acid sites, so it would desorb at higher temperature [47]. The shift of desorption peak to lower temperature might indicate that the proportion of NH3 on Brønsted acid sites increased after phosphorus doping. And the changes of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites will be further discussed afterward. 3.2.5 H2-TPR analysis Fig. 8 presents the H2-TPR profiles of Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti catalysts. A reduction peaks at around 610 °C was observed over both of Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti catalysts. It was reported that the peak at around 610 °C was ascribed to the reduction of CeOCe species and CeOTi short-range order species [22,48]. As for Ce10P3/Ti catalysts, a new reduction peaks centering at 450 °C could be observed, the peak at lower temperature was probably assigned to the easily reducible surface Ce4+/Ce3+species [8,49]. Yao and co-workers [39] reported only one reduction peak around 460 °C over CePO catalyst and only CePO4 phase was observed according to the XRD patterns. Hence, the peak at around 450 °C could be attributed to the reduction of CePO4 species on the surface of Ce10P3/Ti catalyst. After the doping of phosphorus, the intensity of peak at 610 °C decreased significantly. However, the reduction peak of CePO4 species emerged at lower temperature. It suggested that surface CePO4 species owned better redox ability than CeOTi species, which enhanced the SCR activity over Ce10P3/Ti accordingly. XRD patterns showed that surface CePO4 could exist in an amorphous form on Ce10P1/Ti and Ce10P2/Ti, while the crystal phase of monazite CePO4 appeared after a 3 wt.% phosphorus was doped. Meanwhile, the best NH3-SCR activity was obtained. With further doping of phosphorus, the monazite CePO4 accumulated and the SCR activity was inhibited. It suggested that amorphous CePO4 was much more active than monazite CePO4 and the formation of monazite CePO4 might be deleterious to activity. 3.3 In-situ DRIFTS studies In-situ DRIFTS studies were performed to investigate the surface adsorbed species over Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti catalysts. The transient reaction between NO + O2 and pre-adsorbed NH3 species deriving from adsorption of NH3 are shown in Fig. 9 . For Ce10/Ti, the bands at 1548 and 1173 cm−1 can be assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric bending vibration of coordinated NH3 linked to Lewis acid sites [29,47]. However, after a 3 wt.% phosphorus doping, the bands ascribed to symmetric bending vibration of coordinated NH3 shifted to 1236 cm−1 and the bands ascribed to asymmetric bending vibration disappeared. The bands around 1432 and 1599 cm−1 can be assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric bending vibration of surface NH4 + species [14,50]. The bands at 3390, 3259 and 3163 cm−1 can be assigned to the NH stretching vibration modes, the wave trough appearing at 3655 cm−1 resulted from the disappearance of surface hydroxy [29,51]. Comparing the spectra before exposure to NO + O2, after phosphorus doping, the intensity of bands ascribed to coordinated NH3 declined sharply, yet the intensity of bands ascribed to NH4 + species increased obviously. Based on the DRIFT spectra, the ratio of peak area (Brønsted acid/Lewis acid) increased about 20 times after a 3 wt.% phosphorus doping. It suggested that the amount of Lewis acid sites decreased significantly after doping of phosphorus, but much more Brønsted acid sites formed on the surface. According to NH3-TPD profiles, there was an obvious decline of the total acidity after phosphorus doping. The increase of Brønsted acid sites and the weakening of total acidity suggested a dramatic decline of Lewis acid sites. In addition, H3PO4 is a mediate strong acid, and thus phosphate radical might provide a large number of Brønsted acid sites, i.e., the hydroxy groups [37,38]. The existence of CePO4 (on the surface of TiO2) was confirmed by XRD and XPS results, thus the increase of Brønsted acid sites mainly resulted from the hydroxy groups of cerous phosphate. After exposure to NO + O2, for Ce10/Ti catalyst shown in Fig. 9(a), the intensity of the bands ascribed to coordinated NH3 and NH4 + species both decreased gradually and disappeared in 8 min. Then the bands assigned to NO x species appeared quickly. A similar phenomenon was observed over Ce10P3/Ti catalyst as shown in Fig. 9(b), massive NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites (most of them offered by phosphate radical) also gradually disappeared with the introduction of gaseous NO. In the first 8 min, for both Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti, the intensity of bands ascribed to surface NO x species increased slowly. That is to say, NO mainly reacted with adsorbed NH3 rather than adsorbed on the surface of catalyst. However, after the adsorbed NH3 was consumed, the intensity of these bands increased quickly, i.e., NO adsorbed on the surface rapidly and massive nitrate and nitrite formed. The studies confirmed the reaction of adsorbed NH3 (including coordinated NH3 and NH4 + species) with gaseous NO, i.e. Eley–Rideal mechanism. Fig. 10 shows the transient reaction between NH3 and pre-adsorbed NO x species deriving from co-adsorption of NO + O2. For Ce10/Ti catalyst, the bands at 1612, 1576, 1548 cm−1 can be ascribed to the asymmetric vibration of bridging nitrate, bidentate nitrate and monodentate nitrate, respectively, the bands at 1238 cm−1 can be ascribed to symmetric vibration of bridging nitrate [52,53]. After exposure to NH3, an obvious decrease of intensity at 1612 cm−1, assigned to the bridging nitrate, was observed, yet the intensity of bands ascribed to asymmetric vibration bidentate nitrate and monodentate nitrate increased gradually and overlapped at 1566 cm−1. In addition, a peak appeared at the bands of 1238 cm−1 which can be assigned to the overlap of symmetric vibration bidentate nitrate and monodentate nitrate. The order of the stability of surface nitrate was as follow: monodentate nitrate, bidentate nitrate, bridging nitrate. So the decrease of bridging nitrate might be not due to the reaction with NH3 species, but the competitive adsorption with NH3. The introduction of NH3 occupied one adsorption site of the unstable bridging nitrate, thus the unstable nitrate turned into stable bidentate nitrate and monodentate nitrate. As for Ce10P3/Ti, the decrease of bridging nitrate and the increase of bidentate nitrate and monodentate nitrate was also observed. Above all, the reaction of adsorbed NO x species and adsorbed NH3 species, i.e. Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism didn’t played an important role over Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti catalyst in NH3-SCR progress. The in-situ DRIFTS studies revealed that NH3-SCR over Ce10/Ti and Ce10P3/Ti catalyst mainly followed Eley–Rideal mechanism and both coordinated NH3 and NH4 + species could react with gaseous NO. Although the total acidity declined, the doping of phosphorus offered more NH4 + species. So the NH4 + species adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites of phosphate radical must play an important role in the promotion of SCR activity. As shown in Fig. 9(b), the massive NH4 + species indeed disappeared, which illustrated that the NH4 + species adsorbed on phosphate radical reacted with NO via Eley–Rideal mechanism. And NH2 species from the activation of coordinated NH3 and NH4 + species was widely believed to be the important intermediates [22,54]. But these NH4 + species couldn’t be activated by stable P5+ but by nearby Ce4+. Moreover, the existence of active amorphous CePO4 species was concluded by XRD, XPS and H2-TPR results, so a reaction path (Fig. 11 ) via the Eley–Rideal mechanism was proposed to explain the improvement of NH3-SCR performance [5,22,54]. For CeO2/TiO2 catalyst, the coordinated NH3 and NH4 + species could be activated to form −NH2 intermediates by CeOTi active sites. After phosphorus doping, a new reaction path appeared. The NH4 + species adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites of phosphorus could be activated by surface amorphous CePO4 active sites. Because of the excellent redox property of amorphous CePO4 species, the massive NH4 + species adsorbed on cerous phosphate could be activated by nearby Ce4+ (from the oxidation of Ce3+ in amorphous CePO4) to form the important −NH2 intermediates. Hence, the NH3-SCR performance was greatly improved despite of the decline of total NH3 adsorption ability. According to XRD patterns, Ce10P3/Ti might own most amorphous CePO4 species among Ce10P x /Ti catalysts, which accounted for the best SCR activity of Ce10P3/Ti. In addition, through Eqs. (2) and (3), the reduced CeOTi and amorphous CePO4 active sites could be regenerated quickly due to the enhancement of surface Ce3+ and adsorbed oxygen. 4 Conclusions In summary, the doping of P improved NH3-SCR activity over Ce10/Ti. The optimal phosphorus loading was 3 wt.%. Ce10P3/Ti catalyst also showed better under oxygen–rich conditions and wet conditions. The primary reasons for the enhanced deNO x performance are as follows: 1. The enhancement of the ratio of surface Ce3+ and adsorbed oxygen could facilitate the transfer of oxygen on the surface and the regeneration of active sites in NH3-SCR. 2. The surface amorphous CePO4 appeared after doping of phosphorus. The active amorphous CePO4 species could activate the NH4 + species to form NH2 intermediates, then react with gaseous NO much easily. coredata.dc:description: A series of phosphorus-doped CeO2/TiO2 catalysts were prepared by impregnation method and the effects of P on NH3-SCR performance over CeO2/TiO2 were investigated. The P-doped catalysts showed much better deNO x performance than Ce10/Ti catalyst. It was found that the optimal phosphorus loading was 3 wt.% (calculated as P2O5). The Ce10P3/Ti catalyst also exhibited excellent resistance to H2O. The samples were characterized by BET, XRD, XPS, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR and in-situ DRIFT studies. It was found that the ratio of surface Ce3+ and surface adsorbed oxygen species were promoted by phosphorus doping, thus the transfer of surface oxygen and the regeneration of active sites could be accelerated accordingly. Moreover, it was confirmed that the amorphous CePO4 appeared with excellent redox property after the doping of phosphorus. The amorphous CePO4 species could promote NH3-SCR activity by activating NH4 + species on the Brønsted acid sites of phosphate radical, forming NH2 intermediates to react with gaseous NO via an Eley–Rideal mechanism.
coredata.dc:title: The promoting effects of amorphous CePO4 species on phosphorus-doped CeO2/TiO2 catalysts for selective catalytic reduction of NO x by NH3
